reviewText: THE RING has several things working in its favor. Naomi Watts (Eastern Promises, King Kong, Stay) plays Rachel, which gives this movie an advantage right out of the starting gate! Plus, there's David Dorfman as Rachel's creepy son, Aiden. Then, there's Samara the ghost-gal w/ that obscuring veil of hair and that jerky walk! Yikes! THE RING also has a graveyard-ful of cold, bleak atmosphere. This one goes from grey to black very fast! A superior supernatural thriller, THE RING is up there w/ other horror heavyweights like THE SHINING, etc. The music is haunting, the color is drained away, and the images on the dreaded video tape are effectively spooky. THE RING belongs on every horror enthusiast's shriek-shelf...
Title: N/A

reviewText: At a time when horror flicks are a dime a dozen, this one was inovative, fresh , new and never boring. I really liked it. Unlike most of the others, this is not an offshoot of "Friday the 13th". The main problem though, is the point was made about the results of watching the movie with one death in the beginning of the movie. Two more of the kids' deaths would've given the power of the video much more emphasis.It did not have to be gory, just seen by us viewers. If the lady could've saved her child's father in the end and we were left believeing that the family would've been reunited, that would've been a nice touch. This movie runs rings around most of the other stuff, while entertaining, passing as horror these days. Worth buying, watching and watching again.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This review is for the RINGS extra disc that comes with the newly released edition of THE RING.  If you're reading this, you've probably already seen and liked the movie, or at least heard enough about it.The primary attraction of this disc is a short film entitled "Rings," which shows us how the deadly video is spread amongst a group of teenagers, and acts as a lead-in sequence to the second film.  It's well-made, although fans of the original film who thought the remake spelled things out too much will probably feel the same about this.The rest of the features are mostly ones that should have been included on the original, disappointingly bare-bones release: trailers for the movie and the sequel currently in theaters, pure form videos of the "cursed" imagery from these two films and the Japanese original, brief interview clips with Naomi Watts, Martin Henderson, Brian Cox, David Dorfman, Gore Verbinski and the producer, and a very short exploration of the nature of urban legends.If you loved the film and haven't bought it yet at all, it's worth spending a little extra to get this release.  If you have bought the original DVD, I'd advise simply renting this one.  Though the short film is good, neither it nor the other materials are really essential.The five stars are for the film and this package on its own merits.  I offer no stars for Dreamworks' attempt to get us to buy the same product twice.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am one of the six million consumers that bought "The Ring" when it first came out on DVD back in 2003.  Thus, this collector's set piqued my interest when I saw it displayed at my neighborhood electronic store. So is "The Ring-Collector's Set" really worth shelling out the extra bucks for?  After all, it's essentially the original DVD release bundled with an add-on labeled "Rings."  I told myself, "Why not?"  Basically "Rings" is a sixteen-minute short written by the writer of "The Ring" and "Ring Two" and helmed by Jonathan Liebesman, the director of the terrible "Darkness Falls."  But don't let that discourage you.  "Rings" is shockingly good and provides in nice bridge between the two movies.  What really surprised me was the high production values involved in the making of this short.  It could have easily been some lame and cheap throwaway, but the filmmakers really seemed intent on telling a good story.  "Rings" is about a group of teenagers who videotape whichever has recently watched the tape to see how long their sanity lasts.  The most is five days and then another member of the group would watch the tape so the curse would pass on to him or her.  But guess who wants to spoil the fun?  Granted, the short is nowhere near the quality of the original, but I have to admit that I was thoroughly creeped-out.  Disappointingly, the other extras on the disk are basically fillers.  They include dated cast and crew interviews, a three-minute short on myths, movie trailers as well as the original tapes from "Ringu," "The Ring," and "Ring Two."  Again, is the collector's edition worth shelling out the extra bucks for?  It really depends on how well you liked the first movie.  I loved "The Ring" and after watching "Rings" I have to admit that now I'm really hyped on watching the sequel.  And if you're still not sure, Dreamworks included a movie ticket to a free screening of "Ring Two."  Hope that helps.

reviewText: A suspenseful and stylish remake of the Japanese film (Ringu), which lends more plot detail and character development to the bare bones of the original. Unfortunately I did not enjoy this film or the original very much. It is not that either one is bad; neither is my style. Maybe I just don't care much for mysterious horror flicks; maybe it is just that I find Naomi Watts slightly grating. Either way, this one went on just a bit too long and did not really pull me into the story. Watts plays a Seattle newspaper reporter who pursues the mystery behind the sudden deaths of several teenagers. All kinds of supernatural clues point her in the right direction, and she encounters all kinds of ghoulish horror en route to unraveling the mystery. Unfortunately the mystery takes on a more personal dimension and she must solve the mystery in a kind of race against time. By the end of the story, she thinks she has put the mystery to rest and everything is "at peace", but naturally Hollywood cannot leave things be. Ultimately I would have felt this was a better movie IF no sequel were planned.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Spoilers thar be!Morose color schemes, oddball characters and lots of rain apparently make a popular and successful film. While the Ring is an interesting view (once) if you look too closely at this film you'll realize that it's a huge pile of codswhallop that will never add up no matter how much you force it. Let's disassemble...A girl is born to a stray woman but possessed with the soul of a vengeful spirit in need of love and a mother but never in need of sleep. The child is named Samara and adopted by horse breeders Mr. and Mrs. Morgan. But because Samara is cursed with freakyness the horses go crazy and commit suicide while others fail to breed. As punishment for being this way the Morgans trap her in a big attic in a barn. Not content with this they smack her on the back of the head with a rock and chuck her down a well. Their suicides soon follow.Many years later Samara, using her freaky powers at the bottom of the well, somehow brings into existence a video tape featuring a freaky student film of imagery of her freaky life. Anyone who watches this tape dies 7 days later. Which doesn't make sense either as the first person who watched it wouldn't know they were going to die. And neither would the second. So how the urban legend surrounding it got started is a mystery. And why 7 days? Why not right away? Does she want the tape to be deciphered and to be found?A journalist called Rachel investigates the tape, luckily making a copy, ridding herself of the 7-day curse and unravels Samara's freaky life. Her body is found and laid to rest properly. BUT THIS IS A BAD THING! Somehow. It's never really explained why it is but other than the uttering of cryptic dialogue such as 'You let the dead get in'.But bad things don't really happen after this anyway, other than more people watching the video tape. And then everything's okay right? We might as well fade out now...The DVD is in 1.85:1 anamorphic widescreen with highly atmospheric Dolby/DTS 5.1 sound. They call it a 'Collector's Edition' but the only extras are a 'making of' featurette and a short movie called 'Rings', which deserves a review of its own.Rings is the bridge between The Ring and The Ring 2. In the six months between the 2 films the copy of the infamous videotape made by Rachel has multiplied many times (still no explanation as to how people know they're going to die) and it's become such an urban legend that there is a website devoted to it.Jake, the unfortunate high school kid at the start of The Ring 2, has watched the videotape in order to save the life of one of his so-called friends, thus taking on board the responsibility of making someone else watch it in 7 days or die by Samara's fright.Initially Jake is intrigued and is offered a glimpse into the bizarre world of post-videotape viewing that we only saw thru Rachel's eyes in the first. Nothing is explained in any greater detail but the paranormal universe Jake falls into is fleshed-out more and is highly spooky. The short even manages to outdo The Ring 2 by giving us a couple of frights. I don't care how ridiculous the movies are, the image of Samara climbing out the well will ALWAYS be spooky.Anyone who has seen The Ring 2 will already know what becomes of Jake and his would-be girlfriend Emily (the one he forces to watch the tape) but if you're a fan of the films then this is essential viewing. If you've yet to see The Ring 2 then it's the perfect introduction.If you already own the original DVD release of The Ring it's worth trading up for this version if you're dying to see Rings (pun intended). If you couldn't care less then don't bother.
Title: N/A
